testInfo.title: Python Fundamentals Assessment
testInfo.description: Complete the coding tasks below. Focus on data types, variables, operators, and lists.

activities.title: Variable Assignment and Data Types
activities.instructions: Create four variables: 'student_name' (string with your name), 'age' (integer), 'height' (float in meters), and 'is_student' (boolean set to True). Print each variable with its type using the type() function.
hints: Use type() function to show data types
activities.expectedOutput: Show each variable and its type

activities.title: String Manipulation
activities.instructions: Create a string variable called 'message' with the text 'Python Programming'. Then perform these operations: convert to uppercase, convert to lowercase, get the length, and check if 'Python' is in the string. Print each result with a descriptive label.
hints: Use len() to get string length
Use 'in' operator to check if substring exists
Print each result with clear labels
activities.expectedOutput: Uppercase, lowercase, length, and substring check results

activities.title: Arithmetic Operations
activities.instructions: Create two variables: 'num1' with value 25 and 'num2' with value 8. Calculate and print: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, floor division, modulus, and exponentiation. Label each operation clearly.

activities.title: Type Conversion
activities.instructions: Start with the string '42.5'. Convert it to: float, then to int (truncating decimals), then to string again, and finally to boolean. Store each conversion in a different variable and print each result with its type.
hints: Use float() to convert to float
Use int() to convert to integer
Use str() to convert to string
Use bool() to convert to boolean
Print both value and type for each conversion

activities.title: List Creation and Basic Operations
activities.instructions: Create a list called 'numbers' with the values [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]. Then: add 60 to the end, insert 5 at the beginning, print the length, access the 3rd element (index 2), and print the entire list.
hints: Use square brackets to create lists: [1, 2, 3]
Use .append() to add to the end
Use .insert(0, value) to add at beginning

activities.title: List Manipulation and Slicing
activities.instructions: Create a list called 'colors' with ['red', 'blue', 'green', 'yellow', 'purple']. Then: remove 'blue', replace 'green' with 'orange', get the first 3 elements using slicing, get the last 2 elements using slicing, and reverse the entire list. Print the list after each operation.
